q: Why is threshold preparation important for flood barriers?
a: Uneven or porous thresholds compromise gasket compression, allowing seepage. We level surfaces to ±1 mm and seal with polyurethane to meet FEMA TB-3 requirements.

q: What materials work best for rebuilding thresholds?
a: Epoxy mortar or polymer-modified cement provides smooth, non-absorbent surfaces. Avoid silicone caulk—it compresses unevenly under hydrostatic load.

q: How do you treat wooden door sills?
a: We overlay with aluminum sub-plates anchored through to the joist. This prevents water wicking through grain and meets ASCE 24-14 §6.2.

q: Can thresholds be waterproofed without removing the door?
a: Yes. Low-profile retrofit plates slide beneath weatherstripping and use removable edge gaskets. Ideal for historic homes.
Laser levels map the sill plane; we correct variances greater than 1⁄8 inch per 4 ft. Smoother thresholds ensure full gasket contact with Doorway Flood Panels.

q: Do you provide warranty on threshold work?
a: Yes—5 years on bonding integrity and waterproof seal adhesion.
